text: I was the miracle child
I survived something so traumatic that I
wasn't supposed to live
I lost my legs when I was 14 months old
and the story that I know is that my
parents had an affair and had me and my
biological dad couldn't be with my
biological mother so they decided to
commit a family suicide
they strap bombs unto themselves and
held me and then the bomb was around my
legs and they blew me out and so that's
why I lost my legs the fact that I
survived such a traumatic incident it's
kind of crazy I definitely see that
circumstance like a real reason why you
shouldn't just be moping around your
whole life what I love about swimming is
I'm in my legs all day and you know that
it gets really exhausting with swimming
you can't swim with your prosthetic legs
on so when I can take off my legs that
means I have two hours to not be in my
legs not be really uncomfortable
it makes me feel really empowered
because I couldn't really do everything
on my own so that was like the first
thing that I got to do by myself and
truly be free in the water I was adopted
when I was 20 months old so I don't
remember a lot about living in Vietnam
every adopted kid has a gotcha day is
like the day where you were brought home
it's kind of like an extra birthday it
just represents the day that your family
chose you and to their family I have two
brothers and four sisters and 13 nieces
and nephews I know I'm not supposed to
say this but I think I won the adoption
jackpot being in a huge family being in
the Midwest man I had a lot of here they
gave me the best gift I could have ever
imagined Iowa's always surrounded by an
active household so I always knew I was
gonna be an athlete but everybody
thought Oh Ava doesn't have legs like
she'll play the piano and so I told my
parents that I really wanted to try the
active life
[Music]
[Music]
I think after I made my first emerging
time in that for the Paralympics that's
how they track you and that's when you
get a little bit more serious with the
USA that's when it all started to come
together it wasn't just we were gonna
swim five days a week and be just an
okay swimmer you know that's when we
started to add weights and extra
training Queenie the head of the USA
Paralympic swimming she came up to me
and she said welcome to the team like
congratulations you know that was a big
deal I went to Italy over the summer and
I got to swim the USA Paralympic
swimming and I got to where the USA
across my cap I took a picture of it and
like it's real it's real you know - so
I'm pure country means a lot I hope for
my swimming career I go to the 2020
Paralympics being in Tokyo for the USA
really would be the peak of my life
honestly
my able-bodied friends I love being with
them they're always supporting me and
sometimes they don't know what I'm
talking about but I'm also teaching them
a lot about you know the whole other
world that is out there you know there's
more havens out there
